Subject: Using JMock, example of the after() MatchBuilder?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=190580959
X-Yahoo-Profile: cliftonccraig

I am trying to learn JMock and apply it to my unit testing. I'm having
trouble setting up some of the expectations. For example, I want to
set an expectation that a certain method be called exactly 5 times and
set the return value for each invocation. Upon reading the docs I see
an unclear example of how to do this with the onConsecutiveCalls()
stub. So I've come up with the following code on my mockController to
expect no more than 5 calls to the same nextDataModel method. (I threw
in the RuntimeException to stop excessive calls on what works pretty
much like an iterator. The real object doesn't throw on excessive calls.) 

mockParserController.expects(atLeastOnce()).method("nextDataModel")
                .withNoArguments()
                .will(onConsecutiveCalls(
                        returnValue(stubbedZipcodeModel),
                        returnValue(stubbedBusnpartModel),
                        returnValue(stubbedAddressModel),
                        onConsecutiveCalls(
                                returnValue(stubbedCustomerModel),
                                returnValue(null),
                                throwException(new
DTPRuntimeException("No more DataModels available in the stream."))
                        )
                ));

It looks pretty good. But what I'm wondering is if this logic mandates
the method to be called 5 times or if it just set provisions for 5
invocations. I'm thinking the latter. If so then how do I force the
mock to check for exactly 5 invocations (and throw if less than 5)?  I
saw in the docs a mention of the after() method but I don't know
exactly how to use it. It looks like the functionality that I need but
I need an example of it's use.

Cliff
